bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Luis B. Pogolotti, June 4, 1940

div1.p: Hench gives advice on asthma treatment. He returns photographs.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Luis B. Pogolotti, June 4, 1940
div1.opener:
Yellow fever
June 4, 1940
My dear Mr. Pogolotti:
div1.p:
I hope by now you have received the photographs and my other letter.
I certainly appreciated receiving the maps, and I hope you have received some money
from Mr. Moran to pay for the cost of them. If not, let me know, and I will send
you some.

As I wrote you, I have been very, very busy these last six weeks, and have
not been able to do anything much on the yellow fever story. I am going to medical
meetings for two weeks, and thereafter will be able to get at it, and as I promised
you, will certainly send the whole thing when finished, sometime this Summer.

I am sorry indeed to hear that you have been suffering with bronchial astha,
and I wish that you had told me this, as we could discuss the matter more thoroughly
in person than by mail. It is almost impossible to give any definite advice by mail.
We differentiate between asthmatic bronchitis, which we consider to be an infection,
and bronchial asthma, which we consider to be an allergic reaction, somewhat similar
to hay fever. If you have not already done so, I would suggest that you put yourself
in the hands of a physician who is particularly interested in allergy. Your family
physician may know who that might be. If not, you can find out by calling the secretary
of the local medical society or the Academy of Medicine. This physician will give you
a complete examination for allergy. This is a rather difficult and complicated thing,
involving a number of skin tests and other tests. He will doubtless check your nose and
throat and sinuses, to see if you have any infection therein. He will probably advise
the use of iodides or ephedrin pills. In some cases of bronchial asthma, we use
epinephrin spray in a solution of 1:100. The patient inhales as he sprays the back of
the throat.

I know of no booklet or pamphlet for laymen, and hesitate to suggest that you,
a layman, read a medical textbook. However, if the library has Tuft's textbook on
“Clinical allergy”, published by Saunders, might be useful.

If you are unable to get satisfactory results there, may I suggest that at
some time you come up here. It isn't nearly as far as you think, and we should be
delighted to “give you the works”.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. Mr. Louis Pogolotti
Cuba 3
Habana, Cuba
